p.s: Covered entities under the U.S. Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act ( HIPAA ) of 1996 , are health plans , healthcare clearinghouses , and any healthcare provider who transmits health information in an electronic form .
Covered entities need to comply with the HIPAA Privacy and Security Rules in order to avoid penalties .
One of the Security Rule ’s main requirements is the performance of a risk analysis .
The Security Rule stipulates that a risk analysis should be documented but it does n’t require any specific format for it .
This article will present several steps of how to conduct a proper healthcare risk assessment .

list.item:
Define the Scope of the Risk Analysis .
There are different types of risk analysis methods depending on its scope .
The scope of the healthcare risk assessment includes the potential risks and vulnerabilities to the confidentiality , availability and integrity of all ePHI that a covered entity creates , receives , maintains , or transmits .

item.s: Gather Current Documentation .
A covered entity should gather and document information on where ePHI is stored , maintained and transmitted .
This can be done by checking current and past projects , auditing documents .

figure.rend: Conduct a Healthcare Risk Assessment Step 2.jpg

item.s: Identify Potential Threats and Vulnerabilities .
This step is essential to determining the level of risk .
All anticipated threats ( natural , environmental or human ) and vulnerabilities should be documented in category lists and analyzed afterwards .

figure.rend: Conduct a Healthcare Risk Assessment Step 3.jpg

item.s: Analyze Current Security Measures .
All security measures that a covered entity uses to protect ePHI should be documented .
Security measures can be divided into technical – related to the software and hardware in the network - and non-technical – related to management and operations .
This step will reveal whether the covered entity has enough security safeguards in place .

figure.rend: Conduct a Healthcare Risk Assessment Step 4.jpg

item.s: Determine the Likelihood and Impact of Threats .
The covered entity has to analyze each threat and vulnerability combination in order to determine the probability a threat can occur .
The likelihood of threat occurrence can be defined as low , medium and high or can be a numeric representation .
The threat impact should also be defined by using a similar rating system .

figure.rend: Conduct a Healthcare Risk Assessment Step 5.jpg

item.s: Determine the Risk Level .
Make a risk level matrix using the identified likelihood and threat impact .
Choose a rating system such as the low , medium and high rating system .
Add an action description to each risk level , which will clarify to management what actions should be taken to prevent or minimize this risk and when .

figure.rend: Conduct a Healthcare Risk Assessment Step 6.jpg

item.s: Identify New Security Measures .
After identifying the risk level , covered entities have to think what security measures need to be taken to reduce risks .
When defining new security measures , it is important to take into account factors such as the measures ’ effectiveness , legislative or regulatory requirements and other organization ’s policies .
Like each of the previous steps , this step should also be diligently documented .

figure.rend: Conduct a Healthcare Risk Assessment Step 7.jpg

list.item:
EPHI can be found in various electronic media so covered entities should consider all forms of media containing ePHI in their analysis .
Examples of such media are hard drives , floppy disks , CDs , DVDs , smart cards , personal digital assistants ( PDA ) , transmission media , and portable electronic storage media .

item.s: Take into account all possible threat outcomes .

The most common impacts as a result of exploited vulnerabilities are loss or corruption of ePHI , disclosure or unavailability of ePHI , loss of software or hardware inventory , and loss of reputation .
